metadata.titleEn: Spatial-temporal pattern of alpine wetland ecosystem on the Qinghai-Tibet plateau during 2000-2020
metadata.description: 1) Geographic distribution map of water bodies and marsh wetlands in the Tibetan Plateau region, with map codes indicating: 1 for water bodies, 2 for marshes; 2) Data sources: Multiple temporal Landsat TM, ETM+, OLI, SRTM DEM, etc., processed using machine learning techniques; 3) Data quality: 30-meter spatial resolution; 4) Data applications: Revealing the distribution, boundaries, and spatiotemporal dynamics of high-altitude wetland ecosystems in the Tibetan Plateau, providing a geographic reference for field surveys and experiments on wetland ecosystems, and facilitating the management, development, and protection of high-altitude wetlands.

background: The Qinghai–Tibet Plateau, known as the Asian Water Tower, has numerous lakes and is the source of many rivers providing precious water resources for human needs. On the one hand, the formation of water might be changing over a period, e.g., rainfall or snowmelt. Furthermore, the widely distributed glaciers and permafrost in this region have been influenced by climate change and the hydrological cycle appears to have been intensified, resulting in significant area changes of surface water. Previous studies on surface water mapping with 30-m spatial resolution have provided us with unprecedented information for understanding surface water dynamics. Yet, most of these studies extract water information based on one or more years of composite images, instead of benefiting from the whole time series. Mapping surface water from satellites is constrained by the spatial/temporal resolution and geographic/time scope. Studies have revealed that there is a trade-off between the temporal and spatial resolutions of the satellite sensors, with current noncommercial satellites offering either high temporal resolution images with coarse spatial resolution, or high spatial resolution images with sparse temporal resolution. Landsat has been a widely used data source for large-scale, refined, dynamic surface water mapping studies. Since the first sensor launched in 1972, Landsat has provided continuous Earth observations for almost 50 years, which makes it possible for long time series analysis. However, due to cloud contamination and instrumental defects, missing observations may result in uncertainties when using such Landsat images.
research objective: In this study, we proposed a neural-network-based monthly surface water classification framework relying on Landsat 5/7/8 images in 2000–20 and topographic indices, and retrieved monthly water mask for the year 2020. This motivated us to develop a new machine learning algorithm to better improve the retrieval scheme. We show that our approach, based on a neural network classifier, delivers a significant improvement compared to the previous estimates.
challenges: The relatively lower producer accuracy compared with user accuracy indicated that there were omission errors for more than 100 water samples misclassified as nonwater. This problem may be related to cloud contamination, and to the fact there are not enough images to cover all the region within a short time step after the cloud masking.
methods: In this study, we proposed a neural-network-based monthly surface water classification framework relying on Landsat 5/7/8 images in 2000–20 and topographic indices, and retrieved monthly water mask for the year 2020. We developed some solutions for the problem of invalid observations (e.g., missing or negative data), at a finer temporal resolution, which greatly improved the accuracy of the classification results. We conducted a preliminary filtering that greatly reduced the amount of data and the computation cost. We used seasonal models that are stable and robust for the monthly surface water mapping. We collected hundreds of field samples, especially river samples, and unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) images, that can be used to better evaluate the mapping result.
dataset: All available Landsat 5/7/8 Collection 2 surface reflectance images from 2000 to 2020 were utilized here. Figure 1 shows the spatial distribution and histograms of valid observation numbers after filtering cloud and cloud shadow at pixel scale, over the study period between 2000 and 2020. About 90% of the individual pixels obtain more than 300 valid observations. The monthly pixels percentage and spatial distribution of Landsat data were displayed in Figs. A1 and A2, respectively. On average, more than 85% of pixels have one or more images per month.
findings: The overall, producer, and user accuracies of our surface water map were 0.96, 0.94, and 0.98, respectively, and the kappa coefficient reached 0.90, demonstrating a better performance than existing products [i.e., Joint Research Centre (JRC) Monthly Water History with overall accuracy 0.94, producer accuracy 0.89, user accuracy 0.99, and kappa coefficient 0.89]. Our framework efficiently solved the problem of missing data in Landsat images referring to the JRC and a priori information and performed well in dealing with ice/snow cover issues. We showed that higher uncertainties exist on wetlands and recommended exploring relationships between water and wetlands in the future.

background: The Qinghai–Tibet Plateau is rich in water resources with numerous lakes, rivers, and glaciers, and, as a source of many rivers in Central Asia, it is known as the Asian Water Tower. Under global climate change, it is critical to understand the current influencing factors on surface water area in this region. Although there are numerous studies on surface water mapping, they are still limited by temporal/spatial resolution and record length. Moreover, the complicated topographic condition makes it challenging to map the surface water accurately. Surface water is a key part of the water cycle and plays an important role in keeping the balance between terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems. Under the background of global climate change and human activities, surface water resources present different spatio-temporal trends. The Qinghai–Tibet Plateau, the Third Pole on Earth, is a sensitive area to climate change.
research objective: Here, we proposed an automatic two-step annual surface water classification framework using long time-series Landsat images and topographic information based on the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform. This study provides important information for ecological assessment and protection of the plateau and promotes the implementation of sustainable development goals related to surface water resources.
challenges: Although there are numerous studies on surface water mapping, they are still limited by temporal/spatial resolution and record length. Moreover, the complicated topographic condition makes it challenging to map the surface water accurately.
methods: Here, we focus on the Qinghai–Tibet plateau with extensive field investigation and proposed a two-step classification framework, a combination of threshold filtering and RF classification, which reduced the uncertainties of using a single threshold method in a large-scale extent and will prove to be robust and efficient. In this work, we utilized all available Landsat data: Landsat 5 TM, Landsat 7 ETM+, and Landsat 8 OLI satellite images, from 2000 to 2020. All the image preprocessing was performed on the GEE cloud platform. Then, vegetation and water spectral indices were calculated based on the high-quality compositing image, including the normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) and the Automated Water Extraction Index with removing shadow pixels (AWEIsh). To improve classification efficiency and accuracy, a two-step classification framework was proposed for the surface water mapping, which is a combination of threshold filtering and RF classification. First, we draw the potential water extent based on spectral characteristics to exclude areas where there is nonwater with assurance. Then, RF method was used to obtain a more accurate water identification. Pixel-based supervised RF classification was conducted on the GEE.
dataset: In this work, we utilized all available Landsat data: Landsat 5 TM, Landsat 7 ETM+, and Landsat 8 OLI satellite images, from 2000 to 2020. Climate variables during the growing season in 2000–2020 were obtained from the TerraClimate dataset with 4638.3-m spatial resolution. NDVI during the growing season in 2000–2020 was obtained from the MOD13A2 dataset with 1000-m spatial resolution. Active layer thickness data from 2000 to 2019 were obtained from ESA Permafrost Climate Change Initiative (Permafrost_cci) dataset (v3.0) with 926.63-m spatial resolution. Field surveys were conducted along rivers during the growing season of 2020–2021, marking 471 water sampling points. The global surface water body dataset released by the JRC was used for further validation. Sentinel 2 images in 2020 were also used as reference data to compare with our mapping results.
findings: The results showed that the producer accuracy (PA) and user accuracy (UA) of the surface water map in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau in 2020 were 99% and 90%, respectively, and the Kappa coefficient reached 0.87. Our dataset showed high consistency with high-resolution images, indicating that the proposed large-scale water mapping method has great application potential. We found that the mean surface water area was about 59 481 km2, and there was a significant increasing trend ( =322 km 2/year, p < 0.01) during 2000–2020 in the plateau. Greening, warming, and wetting climate conditions contributed to the increase of surface water area. Active layer thickness and permafrost types may be the most related to the decrease of surface water area.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered in the data collection process for surface water mapping on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in the data collection process for surface water mapping on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau is cloud contamination, which causes omission errors in classifying water samples as nonwater. This issue is compounded by insufficient images covering the entire region within a short time step after cloud masking.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used for validating surface water maps in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used for validating surface water maps in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau is the global surface water body dataset released by the Joint Research Centre (JRC). This dataset, along with Sentinel 2 images from 2020, was used as reference data to compare with the mapping results.

Definition.Question: What is a neural-network-based monthly surface water classification framework?
Definition.Answer: A neural-network-based monthly surface water classification framework is a data collection method that relies on Landsat images and topographic indices to classify surface water on a monthly basis. This approach utilizes a neural network classifier to improve retrieval accuracy, handling issues like missing observations and cloud contamination, and allows for the creation of monthly water masks.

Definition.Question: What does the term 'two-step annual surface water classification framework' mean in data collection?
Definition.Answer: The 'two-step annual surface water classification framework' refers to a data collection method that utilizes long time-series Landsat images in combination with topographic information processed on the Google Earth Engine platform. It involves a combination of threshold filtering and Random Forest (RF) classification to map surface water, aiming to reduce uncertainties and improve classification accuracy.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'field samples' and how are they used in data collection for surface water mapping?
Definition.Answer: Field samples refer to the physical samples collected from the field, such as river samples and UAV images, which are used to evaluate and validate the accuracy of surface water mapping results. They provide ground truth data that help in assessing the effectiveness of classification frameworks and algorithms in surface water studies.

Interpretation.Question: How do multi-sensor data integration and the use of topographic indices contribute to the understanding of surface water dynamics?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating multi-sensor data, such as Landsat images and topographic indices, enhances the temporal and spatial resolution of surface water mapping and enables more accurate and nuanced understanding of surface water dynamics, despite challenges like cloud cover and complex topography.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the omission errors in water sample classification when using satellite imagery for surface water mapping?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Omission errors in water sample classification when using satellite imagery can be attributed to cloud contamination and insufficient image coverage to encompass the entire region within a limited timeframe after cloud masking.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to accurately map surface water in regions with complex topography using satellite data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurate surface water mapping in regions with complex topography is challenging due to limitations in temporal and spatial resolution of satellite data, as well as the intricate landscape that complicates the differentiation of water bodies from surrounding landforms.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the uncertainties in Landsat image data, and how do they affect the mapping of surface water dynamics?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Uncertainties in Landsat image data arise from cloud contamination and instrumental defects leading to missing observations. These uncertainties affect surface water mapping by introducing errors in identifying and delineating water bodies, especially in areas like wetlands where higher uncertainties are observed.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact on mapping accuracy when utilizing a neural-network-based method over traditional classification methods for surface water classification?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The neural-network-based classification framework provides significant improvement in mapping accuracy, resulting in overall, producer, and user accuracies of 0.96, 0.94, and 0.98 respectively, and a kappa coefficient of 0.90, which is higher compared to existing products like the JRC Monthly Water History.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of topographic indices influence the accuracy of surface water classification methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integration of topographic indices, when combined with Landsat images, improves the retrieval scheme's accuracy, allowing for better handling of uncertainties such as cloud contamination and instrumental defects, thereby enhancing the mapping results.

Causal Consequence.Question: How do varying spatial and temporal resolutions of satellite data affect the accuracy of surface water mapping on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The trade-off between spatial and temporal resolutions affects mapping accuracy, with higher spatial resolution images offering more detailed mapping but less frequent observations, while higher temporal resolution images provide more frequent observations but with coarser detail. The use of Landsat data balances this trade-off by providing continuous Earth observations that enable long time series analysis, though cloud contamination and missing observations may still pose challenges.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to utilize a combination of threshold filtering and RF classification for large-scale surface water mapping in complex topographic regions like the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: This approach is crucial because it reduces uncertainties associated with using a single threshold method over large areas, providing a robust and efficient method for accurate water identification amidst the region's complex topographic conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of incorporating multiple satellite data sources and field surveys in understanding surface water dynamics on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals include providing a comprehensive and validated dataset that allows for detailed ecological assessment and protection of the plateau, and promoting sustainable development goals related to surface water resources by capturing spatio-temporal trends and influencing factors.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps involved in developing a neural-network-based framework for classifying surface water using satellite images and topographic indices?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves utilizing Landsat 5/7/8 images from 2000 to 2020, incorporating topographic indices, and retrieving monthly water masks. A neural network classifier is employed to improve retrieval schemes, addressing issues of missing or negative data by enhancing temporal resolution, conducting preliminary filtering to reduce data and computation costs, and using stable seasonal models for mapping. Field samples and UAV images are collected to evaluate mapping results.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How does the proposed two-step classification framework on the Google Earth Engine platform enhance the accuracy of surface water mapping on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The framework combines threshold filtering with RF classification, reducing uncertainties in large-scale mapping. All available Landsat images from 2000 to 2020 are processed on the GEE platform. Spectral indices such as NDVI and AWEIsh improve classification efficiency. The first step identifies potential water extent to exclude nonwater areas, followed by RF classification for accurate water identification. The framework is validated using Sentinel 2 images and field survey data.

Enablement.Question: What machine learning advancements have enabled more accurate classification of surface water in remote sensing data?
Enablement.Answer: The development of a neural-network-based classification framework relying on Landsat images and the use of topographic indices have significantly improved the accuracy of surface water classification. This approach delivers better results compared to previous estimates by addressing challenges like cloud contamination and missing observations.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of satellite data sources enhance the understanding of spatio-temporal dynamics in high-altitude wetland ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of multiple satellite data sources, such as Landsat and Sentinel 2 images, as well as topographic and climate datasets, has enabled a comprehensive analysis of wetland ecosystems. This approach provides valuable insights into the distribution, boundaries, and dynamic patterns of wetland areas over time, facilitating ecological assessments and sustainable management efforts.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and methodologies are essential for improving the accuracy of surface water mapping in regions with complex topography?
Enablement.Answer: Utilizing a combination of threshold filtering and RF classification, alongside extensive field investigations and high-quality compositing images, are essential for improving accuracy. This method reduces uncertainties associated with complex topography and allows for more precise identification of surface water in challenging regions.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of machine learning techniques in improving the accuracy of surface water mapping on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: Machine learning techniques, particularly neural network classifiers, have significantly improved the accuracy of surface water mapping on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. They address challenges such as cloud contamination and missing observations, resulting in high accuracy metrics, including overall accuracy of 0.96 and a kappa coefficient of 0.90.

Judgmental.Question: How do you assess the challenges posed by cloud contamination in satellite imagery for surface water mapping, and what strategies could be employed to mitigate these issues?
Judgmental.Answer: Cloud contamination poses significant challenges in accurately mapping surface water due to missing data. Effective strategies include preprocessing techniques on platforms like Google Earth Engine to filter clouds, and using a combination of threshold filtering and RF classification to improve the robustness of water detection.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest a research approach to investigate the relationship between climate change factors and surface water area changes in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau using remote sensing data.
Request/Directive.Answer: A research approach could involve using long time-series Landsat images to analyze surface water area changes from 2000 to 2020. Incorporating climate variables from datasets like TerraClimate during the growing season, NDVI data, and active layer thickness data from Permafrost_cci can provide insights into the impacts of greening, warming, and wetting conditions. Additionally, utilizing a combination of neural-network-based classification and RF classification frameworks on GEE can help correlate climate change factors with observed surface water dynamics.
